Rabies cases increase in northeastern Thailand

Dr. Tawichai of the 9th Disease Prevention and Management Office revealed on February 9 that rabies infections have been increasing in northeastern Thailand over the past few months, with a total of 74 people infected.
So far this year (October last year to September this year), 74 people have tested positive for rabies in the northeastern provinces of Srinakarin and Buri Ram.
They all have had rabies vaccinations in the past.
The doctor is also urging people to get a rabies vaccine along with the pet and to avoid touching the saliva of animals suspected of being infected.
Rabies is not only transmitted by dogs, but also by cats and rats.
If a person gets infected and develops the disease, they will almost certainly die. However, if they are vaccinated before they develop the disease, they can prevent death.

FUJI Placement and Accident Prevention System Development Experiment with Own Vehicles | Midland Economic Newspaper Economic Information on Aichi, Gifu, Mie, and Shizuoka

FUJI (headquarters in Chiyoda City), which manufactures and sells electronic parts mounting robots and industrial machinery, has taken on the development of a system to prevent "abandonment" such as leaving children in cars.
A system that attaches a human detection sensor to the car and sends a notification to the phone or chat when it detects movement.
Currently, we are conducting a demonstration experiment using our own vehicles.
In the midst of accidents that cause pain due to carelessness, protect the safety of children.

Currently, we are conducting a demonstration experiment using two vehicles for the transportation of children to and from our own child-oriented English conversation after-school program "teracoya THANK (TeraCoya SANK)" in the city of Chiyoda.
A human sensor that detects human movement based on the temperature difference between people and the surrounding environment is installed in three places on the ceiling of the vehicle.
If the vehicle's engine is turned off and the door is closed, and if movement of a person is detected after a certain period of time, a warning notification is automatically sent.
By linking the status of the engine and doors, we can prevent as much false detection as possible.
The warning notification is sent through the cloud.
You can either call the number you registered beforehand or display it on your computer or smartphone chat.
You can register multiple addresses, and it's designed to prevent mistakes like overlooking them.
The experiment will continue until the end of February.
Shinmatsu Isoroku, head of the second section of the Innovation Promotion Department, pointed out, "During the experiment, we also noticed peripheral issues that are not part of the system."
For example, it was able to pick up various issues related to school buses, such as creating an environment where drivers can concentrate on driving.
I put my strength into "if we can spread the solution".
The development of the disposal prevention system was triggered by the disposal accidents of the shuttle buses that occurred nationwide.
A member with a young child asked if there was anything that could be done to protect the safety of children.
I decided to develop the technology by leveraging the know-how I gained through FA (Factory Automation) related business, such as IoT (Internet of Things) and sensor information management.
FUJI's anti-removal system is all about convenience.
The sensor can be installed by sticking it to the ceiling.
Because it can be easily added to the escort vehicles, it is aimed at lowering the hurdle of introduction and popularizing it.
In the future, we will continue to seek cooperation from nurseries and kindergartens, and consider productization.

In the city of Kamihama, where a new station is to be built, the details of the station's location have not been revealed, and the city's master plan, which includes the surrounding area, is still in the works.

The city plan centered around the new station will take time to form a consensus among citizens (city official).

【Commentary】 Kanazawa Town is making and distributing Ending Notes to the citizens who want them.

The "okuyami handbook" that was published last year, which includes a list of necessary procedures and forms to be filled out when a family member dies, as well as a family tree, was popular among people who received it for their own use.

In various parts of the prefecture, seminars on how to write an obituary and how to prepare for death are being held, and it seems that "shokkatsu" has become a firmly established practice among the people of the prefecture.
The Ending Note in Enmachi is 35 pages.
It starts with a 5-chapter review of one's own history, and records one's current health and assets, future care, end-of-life medical care, wishes for funerals and graves.
There is also a column to write down things you want to do in the rest of your life and a column to write messages to important people.
I can't even write that there are 35 pages because my bones are about to break, but you don't have to fill up all the pages.
What do you want to leave behind for your family and the people around you?
The most important thing is to make the purpose clear.
In bookstores, there are a variety of notebooks that are suitable for the purpose, and it is said that you can start writing as soon as you can write.
The term "shuukatsu" was coined in 2009.
Two years later, in the 11th year, the Great East Japan Earthquake occurred.
It is said that many people are facing the reality of "death comes suddenly" and are preparing for their own end.
It's been more than 10 years since then.
The new coronavirus pandemic is still raging across the world.
Prices have risen due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and electricity bills this winter have risen to an unthinkable price.
Half of the people are worried about the future because the wages are not enough to match the current prices.

However, in the past, it was common for relatives to share the cost of funerals and nursing care, as well as the management of graves, but now it is rare for a single child to be responsible for these things.
Also, while life expectancy has increased significantly compared to a few decades ago, the risk of dementia and the need for nursing care increases as people age.
I want to keep in mind that the background of this is not just a temporary end to the final innings, but also the rise of social unrest.
Anyway, I think everyone wants to avoid putting too much burden on their partners and children.
"Do it your own way" is a popular keyword among the Ending Note people, but it can't be too self-centered.
I don't want to secretly write down my wishes, but I want to talk to my family once and prepare for it calmly.

The NPO corporation "Heart of Collection Editing Bureau" published the book "Dear Prime Minister, the "Life's Breakwater" from Toshinbo" at their own expense.
I have self-published my 10th book with the title "From the 'Life's Breakwater' East Seikan Monastery".
Each newspaper in the country has picked it up, and many readers have sent in their comments.

The purpose of this book is to share with you the content I have directly heard from those who have attempted suicide in Japan, regarding the "social and structural" environmental issues that are the causes of suicide, and to create a "society where people can live comfortably".

For 18 years and 10 months, we have been patrolling the water's edge in Fukui Prefecture's Toshinomori, which is known as a suicide hotspot, in order to prevent suicide. We continue to support those who are contemplating suicide by discovering and protecting them, and then sending them on their way.

This book is a compilation of the issues raised by the 784 people (2/6 currently) who have been protected so far, and as a request to the Prime Minister of the Cabinet Office, it calls for the following seven items to prevent suicide.
(1) Suicide prevention activities are "life-saving" activities.
(2) Behind the suicide, there is a mountain of "human rights violations".
(3) Suicides are victims of social and structural organized crime.
(4) The administrative agencies treat the citizens who live outside the jurisdiction as "strangers" and coldly treat them.
(5) People with mental illness such as depression are drugged and then commit suicide, but they are treated as "accidents".
(6) The "duty of care" in suicide hotspots is being forgotten as commercialism takes over.
(7) The parts of the teachings of new religious groups that cannot be scientifically proven are deceptive and the act of threatening to curse them in the future and offering them money is blackmail.
It is necessary to publicly denounce and exclude the religious group that committed this crime of "fraud and extortion".

So, we have received many comments from readers of this book, such as "I was moved by the strong mental attitude of those who are involved in this activity," "This former police officer is a model for police officers," and "He is a bodhisattva who lives as if he were a member of his own family, even though he is a stranger," and we would like to introduce one of these comments here.

it's really sad.
everyone is like that.

I felt respect and gratitude for the staff who have been working hard to help people who are suffering so much that they want to die.
I think this activity is a very cruel activity for both the mind and body, but please continue to call out to me in the future as well, if you could be kind enough to do so.
thank you very much.

Berinohotel: Grants for fraudulent use of lodging support program by prefecture and city already returned|Iwanichi Online: Iwanichinichinippo Newspaper Co., Ltd.

On the 10th, the prefecture and one municipality announced that the Berry No Hotel (Yamaguchi, the city) had been inappropriately using the subsidies for the payment of accommodation expenses for travelers for about a year from October 2021.
When non-eligible people stayed, they were given discounts by employees by giving them names.
It was also confirmed that a large number of employees used the lodging facilities for purposes other than "stimulating tourism demand."
The total amount of 7,231,000 yen in grants that were inappropriately used has been returned by the prefecture and the city, as well as the hotels, by the 6th of this month.
The improper receipt of subsidies was the prefectural lodging quota "Iwate Travel Support Project" and the city's emergency lodging quota "First Night Lodging Support Quota".

The period was from October 18, 2021 to October 10, 2022 (the first night stay support deduction was on September 30, 2022), and the results of the investigation showed that inappropriate use, such as use outside the target area and use by those who have not been vaccinated, amounted to 95 cases and 587,000 yen, while inappropriate use that did not follow the purpose and goals of the project amounted to 1,239 cases

It was confirmed that the same person was both the user of the lodging fee and the person in charge of the hotel reception, and the prefecture's business delegation was in the process of conducting an audit.
The prefecture's detailed investigation revealed inappropriate use, and the city also confirmed the facts.
The city's business has already ended, and the registration for the prefectural business was deleted on December 2 last year.

Regarding the investigation, the representative director of the hotel's operator, Berino, Takashi Toritani, said, "I am very sorry to have caused trouble to the people in the region, the prefecture and the city. I am very sorry. I want to start again from zero and work to restore trust as a hotel that exists for the people in the region. " He also said that he plans to hold a compliance training session for all employees.

Chiba Keiyo, head of the promotion department of the prefectural tourism and promotion bureau, said, "I am truly sorry. I would like to continue to promote the proper use of the rules, compliance, and the spirit of the event."
Mayor Sato commented, "I am truly sorry that there were inappropriate uses of the lodging facilities in the city."

Introduction to plant research, including early research by Takayama, and collected materials. Exhibition at the Iwanichi Online City General Cultural Asset Center [Hakodate] | Iwanichi Online, Rock Handai Newspaper Co., Ltd.

The exhibition "People who introduced the flowers of Takadaira-san - A brief history of Takadaira-san plant research" which introduces the pioneers who laid the foundation for the plant research of Takadaira-san, which is known as a treasure trove of mountain plants, is being held at the city's comprehensive cultural heritage center in Ohatsu-machi, Hachinohe, until the 12th.
It introduces the precious samples collected by the forefathers and 124 pieces of data, and the footprints of the forefathers who were involved in the plant research of the early pool peak.

The plant research of Takayama, Hasegawa, and early researchers was started by Russian plant researcher Karl Johann Maksimowitsch (1827-91), who came to Japan at the end of the Edo period, and by Shoichi Hasegawa (1842-1925), who was born in Shibamatsu and collected plants under the guidance of Maksimowitsch.

Maximo Vitch, who was not allowed to freely walk around the country for foreigners, asked for an interview with Shukawa and continued his research for three years with Yokohama and Nagasaki as his base.
After returning to Japan, Sugawara continued to support his research, and this led to the announcement of the "Himekosaka" "Nambuto Uchi Sousou" "Miyamayama Bukishouma".

After that, in 1903 (Meiji 36), the modern plant taxonomist Moriya Tomitaro (1862-1957) published "Nambotranoho", "Kobanotsumekasa", "Nambunazunaza", and in 1905 (Meiji 38), he climbed early Tsukiyama and discovered and named "Katouhakobe", based on local research specimens.
From the exhibition materials, it is clear that many researchers have discovered valuable alpine plants.

Also introduced are Shinozaki Matsuzo (1874-1948), who studied botany while accompanying the survey for the preservation of natural monuments in 1927 (Showa 2), and Yokokawa Nanoru (1914-1988), who was a curator at the Yamanakayama Museum in Otsucho and contributed to the publication of "Yamadake Plants".

Yoshida Masahiro, a researcher at the same center, said, "Each plant in the early pool has a name with a lot of research behind it and connections with people. It can connect researchers from all over the country."

The exhibition is divided into four chapters, and in the first chapter, the faith and history of the early pool peak are introduced, and in the second chapter, the geological characteristics of the early pool peak are introduced based on the research of German geologist Heinrich Eduard Naumann (1854-1927), who laid the foundation of Japanese geology.

Renewable energy introduction and goal negotiations. Okinawa Airport. Second Carbon Dioxide Reduction Promotion Conference|Society/Economy|Nansei Shinyo Shimbun
Promotion Council for Decarbonization of Amami Airport Discusses Plans for Decarbonization = On the 9th, at Kiri-cho, Amami City

The "Amami Airport Decarbonization Promotion Council" (Chairman: Shindo Shuji, Chief of the Kagoshima Prefectural Office's Construction Division, 13 members) held its second meeting at the Amami Airport on the 9th, with the aim of reducing greenhouse gas emissions at the airport.
All members are present, including online.
We held discussions on setting carbon neutrality goals and introducing renewable energy, with solar power generation as the main source.

The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism has set a goal to reduce the greenhouse gas emissions of each airport by 46% or more by 2030, in order to achieve "carbon neutrality" by 2050, which means zero greenhouse gas emissions.
In response to this, the council held its first meeting in November last year, and is aiming to plan and prepare for the other six airports in the prefecture.
The second meeting will be held in the same way as the first, with the exception of the opening.
According to the chairman of the meeting, Mr. Endo, who responded to the interview after the meeting, the meeting confirmed the greenhouse gas emissions from the same airport.
They said that they are pushing forward negotiations in line with the guidelines of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs for the purpose of setting goals and introducing renewable energy.
According to the distribution data, the CO2 emissions of the same airport facilities and vehicles in the fiscal year 2013, which served as the reference, were 1,476 tons (excluding aircraft).

Among them, the lighting and air conditioning of the airport terminal building accounted for about 90% of the total amount of emissions, at 1,321 tons, followed by the airport lighting at 84 tons and airport vehicles at 71 tons.
The council will discuss reducing the emissions of these facilities and vehicles.
Chairman Ando said, "We are now at the stage of passing the bill. The direction of the committee is in agreement, and we want to thoroughly compile the interim report."
In the future, we will make a plan to promote the project after receiving opinions on the interim report at the third meeting and the final report at the fourth meeting.
The "Sakasama Immovable Property" branch office in Nagurabuchi, Okinawa Prefecture, is recruiting people who want to borrow a house on the island. | Society and Economy | Nankai Nichi Shimbun
Opening event deepens understanding of "sakasama immovable property" at talk session, etc. = On the 8th, a well-known town

The opening event of the Sakasama Real Estate branch office in Kagurazaka, which visualizes the thoughts of people who want to challenge things like vacant houses and vacant shops, and solicits landlords, was held on the 8th at the famous community space "entaku", which is a famous town.
The operator company will explain the overview of the same service through the talk session.

Takahiro Oki, the representative director of Tsuginoha (Likoro-gun, Hokkaido), which is in charge of branch operations, said, "If we do this in the Oki Islands, we can create a movement and flow that will bring people together across the entire island."

Sakasama real estate is the opposite of normal real estate procedures, where the borrower's information is disclosed to the lender and they contact each other to reach an agreement and then sign a contract.
As a pilot project to explore vacant houses and build relationships through them, the company On-Co (headquarters in Mie Prefecture) began operating the service in June 2020.
This is the seventh branch office opening in Kyushu.
It's the first time in the country.
About 20 people participated in the event, including On-Co and Tuginoha staff, and employees of the Yokohama branch of the Yokohama Chamber of Commerce, as well as local residents.

Daiju Fukube, the representative director, explained the background of the branch office opening, saying, "I thought that if we could utilize vacant houses and vacant shops, the town and the island would become more lively as the movement to attract people from outside the island becomes more active."
"I want to help by connecting people who have properties on the island or who want to do something with us, and to help them move forward one by one."

On the other hand, Co's Mizutani Yoshiaki pointed out the need to discuss how to manage the vacant houses, such as what criteria to use to select the people who will live in them, and who will manage them, and how to manage them.
He called for the participation of islanders in the talks and the provision of information, saying, "If people are connected deeply, information will be gathered deeply."
